Title: Projection map being a closed map
Content: Let $\pi: X \times Y \to X$ be the projection map where $Y$ is compact. Prove that $\pi$ is a closed map. First I would like to see a proof of this claim. I want to know that here why compactness is necessary or do we have any other weaker condition other than compactness for the same result to hold.
AcceptedAnswer: There is a standard example for why some hypothesis on $Y$ is necessary: let $X=Y=\mathbb R$ , and consider the closed subset $F=\{(x,y)\in \mathbb R\times\mathbb R:xy=1\}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^2$ . What is its projection to the first factor? In fact, one can prove that a space $Y$ is compact iff for all spaces $X$ the projection $X\times Y\to X$ is closed. So while compactness is not necessary (I think...) for the closedness of the projection for one $X$ , it is necessary if you want all such projections to be closed. As for the proof you want in the first bullet point... this is a standard exercise in topology: what have you tried?

Problem:
Let X and Y be topological spaces, with Y being compact. Let π: X × Y → X be the projection map defined by π(x, y) = x. Prove that π is a closed map.

Proof:
To prove that π is a closed map, we must show that for any closed set A ⊆ X × Y, its image π(A) is a closed set in X. We will do this by showing that the complement of π(A), which is X \ π(A), is open.

Let A be a closed set in X × Y. Let x be an arbitrary point in X \ π(A). By definition, this means that for all y ∈ Y, the point (x, y) is not in A.

Since A is closed, its complement (X × Y) \ A is open. For each y ∈ Y, since (x, y) ∈ (X × Y) \ A, there exists a basic open set U_y × V_y in the product topology such that (x, y) ∈ U_y × V_y and (U_y × V_y) ∩ A = ∅. Here, U_y is an open neighborhood of x in X, and V_y is an open neighborhood of y in Y.

The collection of sets {V_y | y ∈ Y} forms an open cover of the space Y. Since Y is compact, this open cover has a finite subcover. That is, there exist a finite number of points y₁, y₂, ..., y_n in Y such that Y = V_{y₁} ∪ V_{y₂} ∪ ... ∪ V_{y_n}.

Now, consider the corresponding open neighborhoods of x: U_{y₁}, U_{y₂}, ..., U_{y_n}. Let U be the intersection of these sets:
U = U_{y₁} ∩ U_{y₂} ∩ ... ∩ U_{y_n}.
Since this is a finite intersection of open sets containing x, U is an open neighborhood of x.

We claim that U is entirely contained in X \ π(A), which is equivalent to showing that U ∩ π(A) = ∅.

To prove this, let's assume for the sake of contradiction that there is a point z ∈ U ∩ π(A).
If z ∈ π(A), then there must exist some w ∈ Y such that (z, w) ∈ A.
Since {V_{y₁}, ..., V_{y_n}} is a cover for Y, w must belong to at least one of these sets, say w ∈ V_{y_j} for some j ∈ {1, ..., n}.
Also, since z ∈ U, we know that z ∈ U_{y_j} for that same j.
Therefore, the point (z, w) is in the set U_{y_j} × V_{y_j}.

However, by our initial construction, the set U_{y_j} × V_{y_j} is disjoint from A, i.e., (U_{y_j} × V_{y_j}) ∩ A = ∅. This contradicts our finding that (z, w) ∈ A and (z, w) ∈ U_{y_j} × V_{y_j}.

The contradiction shows that our assumption was false. Thus, there is no such point z, and U ∩ π(A) = ∅. This means U ⊆ X \ π(A).

We have shown that for any arbitrary point x ∈ X \ π(A), there exists an open neighborhood U of x that is completely contained in X \ π(A). This proves that X \ π(A) is an open set. Consequently, its complement, π(A), is a closed set in X.

Since A was an arbitrary closed set in X × Y, we conclude that π is a closed map.
